definition: Sergius Paulus
a slave, servant;
a female slave, servant;
to be in bondage to, subject to;
a god or goddess, a deity in a polytheistic sense
The term for God from the Israelite and Christian monotheistic perspective
Christ referred to directly as God
God, as the one supreme supernatural being as creator and sustainer of the universe
Man or a part of man considered as god
The devil as the god of this world
coordinating conjunction
connects elements of a list
an adversative, or contrasting, conjunction
signals a change to a new scene, time, location, or topic in narrative
signals a change to a new speaker in dialogue or actor in narrative
correlative conjunction
gloss: on the one hand , but on the other hand

definition: the name of Jesus Christ the son of God
The name of the leader who succeeded Moses and led the nation Israel into the Promised Land
the son of Eliezer in the genealogy of Jesus Christ
another name given to Justus a ministry partner of the Apostle Paul
an additional name given to Barabbas (which only appears in some manuscript families)
the Christ, or Messiah;
Showing downward motion, indicating movement downward
gloss: down, down toward, down into, down from, down upon, down to, downward

definition: Used to communicate motion throughout an area or to indicate that an action takes place throughout an area
Denoting place or location or extension in some place
gloss: on, along, in, over, through, around

definition: Indicating some aspect of time occurrence--when indicating a time occurrence kata can indicate specifically when something occurs or it can indicate the approximate time that something occurs or it can be used to indicate that something takes place on a recurring basis in which case it can be translated as every or each
gloss: in, at, at the time of, when, during, about, every, each

definition: Used to indicate opposition or hostility against someone or something
Used to indicate that the position of someone or something is oriented in a certain direction, located in a certain location, or moving in a certain direction
A position or location that is exactly opposite another position or location, a position directly facing another position
Used with oath giving to indicate who or what one swears by
Used to indicate a purpose or goal
gloss: for the purpose of, for, to

definition: Used to show correspondence
gloss: according to, in accordance with, corresponding to

definition: Used to mark somethings relationship to something else
gloss: in relation to, with regard to, with reference to

definition: belief or trust in a person or thing
Assurance regarding something, confidence
Christian beliefs as a whole, Christian doctrine, the Christian faith/teaching
fidelity, faithfulness, trustworthiness, the state of being reliable or worthy of trust
A pledge, a vow, a pledge of faithfulness
proof or assurance of something, a pledge, a guarantee
a god or goddess, a deity in a polytheistic sense
The term for God from the Israelite and Christian monotheistic perspective
Christ referred to directly as God
God, as the one supreme supernatural being as creator and sustainer of the universe
Man or a part of man considered as god
The devil as the god of this world
Used as a connecting word to connect single words to each other
Used as a connecting word for the purpose of connecting clauses and sentences together and showing their connection or continuity with each other
Used to show a close time connection or time sequence between events
Used to introduce the result of something that happened beforehand
Used to explain by giving the reason for what came before
Used to introduce a sudden question
Used as a pair "καί  … καί" to combine two things or ideas into one thought or unit
gloss: and...also, both … and, not only …, but also

definition: Used to emphasize an unexpected or important fact
gloss: and yet, yet, how is it then, nevertheless, in spite of that

definition: Used to indicate the beginning of a new sentence
gloss: Depending on the language this use of καὶ is being translated into it may be best to leave this use of καὶ untranslated at times or to translate it in a way that is most natural to the target language

definition: he, she, it, this one, that one, the (referring to an identified entity, as in Acts 17:28)
the one . . . the other
but he, but they (in narration)

the, this.  Defining an entity, for example.  Individualizing, focusing attention on an entity as something or someone unique or known (as in John 1:1).  The word may refer to a common noun mentioned before (for example, as in Matt. 2:7) or receiving special attention (as in John 19:5).  When used generically, the word focuses attention on an individual as representing a class (as in Luke 10:7)
the

the.  Added before other parts of speech, marking substantive use (functioning as a noun).  For example, with a neuter adjective (as in Eph. 6:16 and Rom. 9:22), participle (which often may be translated as relative clauses, as in Matt. 4:3), or infinitive (forming an articular infinitive, as in Rom. 7:18 and 1 Cor. 16:4)
the, this (used in the neuter form before sentences, phrases, or single words which may then be regarded as quotations or sentence topics, as in Eph. 4:9 and Heb. 12:27)
the (used before prepositions with prepositional phrases, or with an adverbial expression, as in Rom. 9:5)
the son of, the things that pertain to (used in the genitive to denote kinship, ownership, or association, as in Matt. 10:2 and Rom. 14:19)
